posts.com:
This board is for the discussion of classic, or "retro" games, including consoles, computer games, arcade games (including pinball) and any other forms of video games. Retro gaming means platforms launched in 2001 and earlier, and official game titles for those platforms released no later than December 2007 (homebrew console games made after this date will be permitted). The Microsoft Xbox, Nintendo GameCube, Nintendo Game Boy Advance, and Sony PlayStation 2 will now be considered "retro".

Helpful links:
Game Tech Wiki
Emulation General Wiki

When it comes to hours of gameplay in a game, so many people focus on quantity. For me, the quality of those hours is far more important. I don't need to squeeze 100+ hours out of a single game anymore.

posts.com:
>>9512079
>it was a third pillar

I remember being on the NeoGAF forums in 2003 and reading the flame wars between the Sonyfanbots and Nintendodoids (or whatever they were called) around the PSP and DS. Sony announced the PSP first. Then Nintendo made an announcement that they were making a new handheld that would have two screens, shortly after. Which lead to a lot of speculation. Before both systems were released, people thought that Sony was going to crush Nintendo in the handheld market. But it turned out to be the opposite, as the DS dominated, and the PSP still sold really well. Because the GBA really was selling well with a lot of third party support, Nintendo made that 'the DS will be out third pillar" comment. In the end, the GBA still sold well alongside the DS and DS having backwards compatibility with the GBA helped a lot. People were buying GBA games for their DS.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
As far as I know Nintendo's handhelds always did really well for them. They iterated a lot on the hardware. Even the GameBoy Color wasn't really a platform of its own--it was the umpteenth version of the GameBoy. If anything, for the relatively short cycle of its life as the most current Nintendo handheld, it sure had a lot of longevity, success, and a big library of good games.

It seems silly to say this but technology was advancing so rapidly then, in such an immediately noticeably way. It seemed amazing to have something akin to the SNES in your pocket and then in only a few years the DS and the PSP were just shy of their console counterparts, for the most part. No doubt helped by the screen size.

Now Nintendo has no second pillar, but what they have produced is likely on its way to becoming the best selling game console of all time. But I do wonder if they would ever introduce another pillar, a separate and distinct hardware. I'm assuming the next thing will be a close iteration of the Switch though.

I guess in 2001 GBA was the right hardware for the price for Nintendo. Later, maybe the feared competition more, so they launched SP.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9520750
>I honestly hadn’t personally heard the term smart phone before Apple’s iPhone came to the market.
I can see that happening. Around 2001–2004 I was reading a lot of mobile tech mags, so I was used to seeing the term "smartphone" everywhere. But if you asked some random guy, he might have said "never heard that word". It wasn't that popular outside of its bubble, at least nowhere near current day level when everyone and their mom have had smartphones for years. Mostly tech-savvy types with used those, and those who clearly had some cash to afford them. PDAs were even more rare (at least where I lived), plenty people didn't know they existed, and few had one.
>We are sort of stuck in this stagnant time for phones without any major innovations what so ever. It’s bizarre.
The truth is, you can only invent something once. Like you can't just invent Wi-Fi again, or frontal phone camera again.
But in the 90–2000s, there were a lot of new tech advances, some fundamentally new things, like e.g. Wi-Fi—they just weren't popularized yet. And we had a whole new transition of old tech going digital, mobile, and wireless—digital cameras, digital media storage, 3G, etc. And once more, you can't just "transition to digital" again—it happened once, and that's it.
A lot of the tech that iPhone introduced wasn't exactly "new", it had been floating around for years. It simply got mature enough for mass market around late 2000s–early 2010s. Kind of like how VR had been around since forever, but got truly big only in recent years.
But sooner or later, you implement all of those ideas that were "floating around". The competition all copies each other and there's not much new to introduce. You basically use up all the innovations that had accumulated for decades.
So yeah, phones have been stagnating. But that's just because the "transition to digital" is largely over, it has been done, perfected, and now it's just marginal improvements.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9520750
>>9520873
Also, to add, in many things we've reached the point where "enough is enough" in phones.
There used to be a race for screen size, but then everyone realized that going over 6 inches screen is retarded. The DPI race is also over, because frankly, the difference between Full HD phone and 4k phone is negligible. Phone cameras still do improve, but the megapixel race is also kinda over. Going thinner and lighter is not really impressive anymore. Processors and graphics? You already have pretty damn strong CPUs in phones, considering most people use them only to play cookie clickers, and many phone games look about as good as console ones. Hell, I think Apple was the first company ever to use 5-nm chips in their tech. Storage? Stopped being a problem with 128gb phones becoming the norm. Internet? 4G already offers 100-300mbps on paper, that's more than enough in the era of streaming.
Then again, in other things we're just simply stuck (kinda). Batteries haven't really gotten that much better, they just get bigger with phones, and it's not like we ever got 10x more charge in them in recent years—hence why battery life is still often shit. 5G is coming, but it will need time to roll out, and not like it's going to get cheaper—perhaps the opposite.

>>9523968
The hardware is deigned like a 2D system what with it's dedicated sprite and background layers, similar to a SNES or a Genesis except more powerfil. Sprites can be arbitrarily scaled, skewed, distorted on all 4 points, allowing devs to do real fake 3D on the Saturn. The background layer is kind of like the SNES, mode 7 effects et-al.

The problem is that due to the sprite nature of the Saturn, you can't really do any advanced 3D effects like reflection mapping due to no real UV mapping support or advanced blending effects.

>>9523983
The PS1 was designed like a real (albeit limited) 3D system from the start with it's hardware accelerated transformation via it's GTE and support for other 3D rendering features.

>>9522024
Playing the game for the first time before there were guides and everything was solved was a magical experience. I imagine the same goes for a lot of MMORPGs of that time. The human interactions were more genuine, you had to barter and trade for the items you wanted instead of just using a global marketplace menu, it really felt like you were on an adventure and part of something bigger. You banded together with other random newbies to explore the world and get stronger, eventually guilds and friendships were formed and some people even married IRL.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9522054
yeah man, RO was something special. i started playing during beta of 2002 (before there were even 2-1 classes), and there's never been anything else like it. i still remember when you could do crazy shit like warp monsters or use DBs in town. everything was so rudimentary and dependant on player interaction like you said; there wasn't even a world map for the longest time. it felt like you were just plopped into this strange land and had to figure everything out on your own, and it was the best feeling. want to sell your shit for top dollar? you've got to make a merchant, pick a spot in the world, come up with a catchy shop name and start your own store -- and if you kept up with it, you could forge your own little niche, like being "the guy who sells potions outside the dungeon" or "the guy who sells elemental claymores in west pront". the game had a humbleness but also let you create own identity and legend. that's to say nothing of what is probably the best OST in any game ever made and timeless graphics. RO was amazing. i still go back every few years to whatever server pops up; it's definitely a shell of its former self, but even now, i still catch that little fleeting feeling of warmth that it gave me as a kid. truly one of the greats.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9518587
I'd make this top 10
1. Castlevania: Aria of Sorrow—must play for everyone. If you pick just 1 game, make it this one.
2. Rhythm Tengoku—best rhythm game I've played. Play if you like quirky games like Wario Ware and rhythm games.
3. Advance Wars—personally not a fan, but those who liked it spent hundreds of hours in it. Very addictive strategy game.
4. WarioWare—quirky and addictive, one of the more original games for GBA. If you've never tried it, do. If you did, still fun to see where it all started from.
5. Metroid Fusion—it's 2D Metroid, enough said. It's great despite some say it's not Super Metroid.
6. Mother 3—not a perfect RPG, but one many people want to play now. Play if you like Earthbound or want an RPG with plot.
7. Wario Land 4—some praise this is as pinnacle of GBA or even best platformer ever, others will write it off as good but ultimately weaker than the GBC ones. Regardless, well worth a try.
8. Mario & Luigi—actually very good RPG, only brought down by bing bang wahoo style and kinda whatever graphics.
9. Kirbies in general—always fun and worth a play. Play if you like Kirby, don't play if you're sick of platformers.
10. Mega Man Zero 3 & 4—decent games, but got pretty overrated recently as some "official canon classics". I beat them all, they're fun and good but not really masterpieces. Play if you like Mega Man X series and / or have played the other 9 games already.
Not on the list:
SNES ports, especially Mario ports—kind of obsolete in current day and age, maybe save for SMW as you can collect dragon coins in it, but that's it.
Pokemons—you either love them or hate them. If you love them, you probably know which ones to play anyway, and may prefer remakes.
Zelda: Minish Cap—it's more Zelda. Play it or skip it, it's alright if you want more ALTTP but thats about it.
Treasure games—no comment.
Mega Man Battle Network—one of those monster / card collect series that just goes on and on.

Just don't be like countertop faggot and buy a desoldering gun before a fucking multimeter. What a dumb cunt.
- Soldering iron
- Solder
- Flux
- Some kind of fan for blowing or sucking up fumes
- Some low-gauge wire for bodging
- Multimeter
- Side cutters

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9519535
I did get a desoldering pump, it was included with the soldering station as well as the solder itself. It's a 60/40 solder which I understand is the most common one. At this point, I would worry to much about the type of solder, the one you buy at the hardware store is going to be just fine, but if you must know, there is a type of solder material that includes flux inside the solder tube. From what I understand, you really want to get some flux so that you can break the oxidation surface in most metallic components and the solder sticks to it properly. I think that is more important.
And as far as removing solder goes, I'm going to use a desoldering pump, but you may also you those desoldering copper braids.

>Also how do you extract components without fucking up the solder pads

instead of a "repair kit" you can improvise with a piece of copper wire or a trace-thin piece of copper foil

Haven't needed to solder anything in a while since I basically completed everything I needed to do. Recapped a few old consoles that were malfunctioning or experiencing issues like audio hum. Did an RGB mod for my N64. Made an entire set of my own RGB cables for everything I needed, etc.

Most proud of actually successfully doing the NESRGB installation, something I had been putting off for a while beforehand. I don't have a desoldering gun but by some miracle I was able to take out the PPU without damaging the fucker. I also desoldered/disassembled the power/RF-modulator daughterboard, took out the RF circuitry, and repurposed the hole for the RGB mini-din port, as well as repurposing the channel select switch to now turn the NESRGB on/off.

Maybe at some future point I'll recap my spare 24" trinitron. It has some weird geometry issues and the red values can't ever get quite right, and slowly creep up or down depending on the drive setting. I assume it's a capacitor issue somewhere.

Post for blog contribution to the board: I tried to solder a new battery onto a copy of Smash Bros 64, since the unlocked content / stats would reset everytime the power went off and I figured it was the problem. I have only the vaguest memories of soldering from back when a took an intro electronics class in high school (not recent).
It still doesn't save anything when the N64 powers down, so I don't know if I messed up the soldering or if the problem was actually do to some other fault on the board (seems unlikely though). I didn't have access to flux, or any kind of solder sucker/remover (never used one in high school and didn't know it existed) so I basically just melted a bunch of solder over the new battery terminals and hoped for the best. This was a few months back, so I can't recall if I used a multimeter to confirm the battery connection was good or not.
I'm not sure if if it's worth investing in some sort of additional soldering tools, or even what they would be, and practicing my skills since at the moment it's my only piece of electronics that I might have to repair. I'll be annoyed if I buy two new pieces of gear, re-solder the new battery (admittedly it's a fast process), and then find out the game STILL doesn't work correctly. It just seems like a lot of learning and shopping for a fix that might not work.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
It's a very good game, with extremely strange mechanics. The problem is that the in-game tutorials are shit, and the mechanics are at times contradictory and counter-intuitive. But it's worth playing for the story, music, and graphics.

Weapons have type, affinities, and class. Learn what these mean from an online guide. Be aware that it'll be impossible to match them up perfectly, and (even if you could) it would be tedious to swap your weapon for every enemy. FYI, type has an outsized role in the damage calculation, affinity is medium, and class is the least. So just focus on type and ignore the others, but you may switch for affinities very rarely if it's a big encounter and you have a great weapon for it.

Read how crafting works online. You MUST craft and you MUST know how combinations work. Drops in chests are shit.

There's an optional dungeon. Get to the end of the first floor and use the item they give you for crafting. It's phenomenal against the final boss.

If you get good stat bonus rolls, stay current with competent crafting, and use the correct type, you'll become OP and finish most end-game boss fights in just a few rounds.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9522394

You don't need a guide.
The weapon crafting in this game is similar to demon fusion in SMT games.
The game throws a lot of weapons at you through drops/chests and it's up to you to fuse them into better ones.
You can simply go to a blacksmith's shop and try combining random ones to see what you get.
Some combinations give you a similar weapon, some the same but augmented, some a weapon of a higher tier and some a completely different "type". You can easily experiment with all this on your own and figure it out on the go.

The idea is to upgrade your weapons but keep an eye on the stats so certain ones keep improving etc...

Just remember that sometimes the bosses end up simply having a type that you don't have a weapon for and then you might want to brute force them by chaining a lot of abilities or so on.
Also different parts of bosses (head/legs/arms/etc) have different vulnerabilities. It's not usually decisive but it gives you an option to target something else and see if you get better dmg numbers.

A lot of the battles later on involve stacking a lot of high risk chain abilities and then reducing the buildup of risk with items quickly before doing another chain.

>>9523212
I think it depends on what kind of household you grew up in. In my home games were an occasional treat. My dad hated when I got more of them. I grew up not knowing that buying used games was even a thing. So of course I didn't get guide books or magazines either. I would just play games until I got too bored or frustrated to continue. Completing levels felt great but beating the game was not the objective, the objective was to have fun and keep that going.

I never saw the ending to SMB1 and didn't feel it was important to see one. After all, cartoons don't end, they just keep having episodes after episodes, so why should a game have to end? That's bad. Just like if my favorite cartoon ended altogether. My first console was the NES and we got a garage sale Atari and C64 as well. Most of those games had no ending so I thought it was normal.

I remember Commando on NES was probably the first game I ever beat. To me I was just exploring the game, seeing new levels and environments. Then all of the sudden I see the Congratulations screen. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9523212
>How often or how quickly would you beat games?
Fairly rarely, in fact. Depends on the game. Beatemups are usually easy to clear in a sitting, and RPGs, while they take time, are just a steady grind of getting stronger until you win. There are some games where, as a kid, my bros and I would play for a bit, have fun, then swap cartridges to something else, with some titles remaining perpetually unbeaten. But we were never particularly bothered by it. It sounds like a bizarre thing to say, but "you have to be able to beat it" never felt like a required selling point back in the day. Just trying to get farther for the explorative reward of seeing the next level or the new enemy types was exciting enough. It was fun to be able to go to school the next day and tell kids "dude I got to level 4 once and there's these grey octopus things that shoot missiles!" on some game.

Part of it comes down to ownership vs rental though. It wasn't common for kids in our region and generation to own lots of games, we weren't super rich. So we'd get one or two a year for birthday/Christmas, and borrow them between ourselves. When rentals became a thing it greatly expanded the number of titles we were able to play, and at only 3 days a pop it was common to return a game without clearing it, to try something else, then come back to it and rent it again at a later date (unless it was so awesome that it was worth renting multiple times in a row; when Street Fighter 2 came out on SNES I think we stayed up 25 hours playing that).

I do have some distinct memories of games I did beat, though. Zelda 1 multiple times - always an immersive adventure. Final Fantasy 1 as well, and grinding or no the last dungeon can get tricky if you're not smart with your spellcasting. Castlevania 1, was pretty proud when I could sit down and beat that in a single run. NES Strider, loved the music and anime intro to that (and we wouldn't know what "anime" was for a couple more years)

>Its almost unanimously agreed that TP has the best 3D dungeons in the series followed by OOT
That's actually just a big cope because the game has no other strengths to fall back on. If Zelda fans knew a good dungeon from a bad dungeon then we would have seen pushback in the past ten years of dungeons being removed from zelda in ALBW and BOTW.

What does TP actually have to compete with OOT? Arbiter's grounds is a shit version of forest temple with a worse aesthetic and a very limited dungeon item. Sky temple's puzzles are so simplistic as to be damn near automated. the water dungeon has a good idea in its central chamber but no fun side rooms to back it up. The first dungeon doesn't have the verticality nor the practical solutions of deku tree. Goron Mines is straight hot ass, the dungeon item is slow and plodding while involving no decision making, and it's basically a hallway. Temple of Time is fun, and the Yeti's house is GREAT, but they can't make up for the others being so merely competent.

posts.com: Fable is a terrible series. the first game wants to be Gothic and instead plays like a down syndrome Ocarina of Time. everything in the game is painfully incohesive. high fantasy adventure? no, fuck you, here's a sassy female POC in the first 10 minutes. good combat? no, fuck you, here's a beat 'em up where you knock enemies around like rag dolls for 20 hits until they die in a ridiculously unsatisfying way and then you absorb their exp manually. but what about exploration? nope, fuck you. the entire world is a series of narrow, linear paths with absolutely nothing interesting to find outside of vaguely homosexual anthropomorphic doors that force you to complete some mundane task to see what's behind them. but of course, dealing with bullshit retarded mechanics is part of any RPG -- you're there for the depth, right? nope. fuck, you. there's no depth. armor is meaningless, weapons have no interesting modifiers beyond the genre standards, the game keeps track of dozens of pointless statistics (including your character's sexuality, to make sure you won't feel marginalized if you're a faggot; a.k.a. the target demographic), the spells are milquetoast fireball garbage, the quests are tantamount to jogging simulators, the minigames are insultingly simplistic (e.g. the 'fishing' which involves walking over to a pre-defined spot and pressing a button and waiting for something to happen), and at no point is there any allocation of stats or skill points with any meaningful impact on your character's growth that can't be changed or reverted... and the sad part is, this is the best game in the series. Fable 2 is more of the same except with a depressing Pirates of the Carribean setting and even fewer RPG elements (except for more homosexuality stats, like contracting herpes from fucking a gay man in the ass in your house), and Fable 3 is once again more of the same, except this time you can grow wings to fully realize the fairy you are. fuck Fable and fuck you.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9517751
Unmodded Oblivion is dogshit from a gameplay perspective, anyone who tries to argue otherwise has either not played past level 20 or has not touched the game in 15 years. Barely any feedback compared to the meaty thwack and stagger animations in Morrowind, and bloated HP pools to offset hit chance being removed means you end up with monotonous 5 minute slap fights every two or three minutes. Aggressive level scaling on everything will either have you tearing you hair out trying to keep an edge against enemies in the next bracket ahead of you or constantly throttling the difficulty slider up and down to just be able to play the game without getting reamed by the hundreds of ogres and minotaurs that will eventually spawn in the wilderness. Individual quest premises are usually fun or entertaining, but most of them are not very well realized, and the big quest lines easily have some of the lamest writing and design in the game. The voice acting, endearingly shit NPC AI, and overall comfy atmosphere are Oblivion's saving graces, and I suspect they're the primary reason more people aren't harsher when evaluating it. It really does feel like Bizarro Morrowind sometimes, since almost every issue someone may have with Morrowind is """""fixed""""" by Oblivion, but every problem with Oblivion has a design-level solution that already existed in Morrowind.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9520838
Here's a good example from the second game. A door opens up and there's an axe-throwing zombie in front, a weak zombie to his right, and a strong zombie behind that one. You've got two ways you can go about this: You can either start by killing the axe-thrower then try to carve through the strong zombie and weaker zombie guarding him before they reach you. Or you can ignore the axe thrower and prioritize getting rid of the stronger zombie. The later method eliminates any threat of the strong zombie reaching you, but it requires having to shoot down an axe projectile while you're doing it.

That's not even getting into stuff like score items that often have a small window to collect in the middle of a zombie attack.

That was in 64? Shit, my memory is bad, I thought it was the original game where you could do that on one level.
>shit in vidya you never figured out until decades later
Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles on NES has a feature where if you hit your turtle's head on a ceiling or obstacle, your forward momentum is dropped. So if you ever hit your head, you aren't jumping as far as you could have if you didn't hit. Not knowing this detail is why I never got past level 3 as a kid, since there's one jump in the game in level 3 that requires you to know this. I somehow never noticed.
Twisted Metal 2 has a rear-view mirror you can bring up, making it a lot easier to avoid getting ambushed from behind. As a child I beat the game on Normal with every character without ever knowing about the mirror, just the freeze shot, shield, and jump combos. Today I struggle to reach the end with the mirror and anyone who isn't fucking easymode Minion.
Kirby's Adventure has a hidden door on the first level with a UFO. Neat, but pretty much pointless since you always lose UFO on leaving a level. I found every other hidden door in the game as a kid, except that one.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9516995
>AI's getting better, soon we won't need to learn Japanese,
It's really not. It appears like it is because the end result is usually correct English, but the quality of the translation itself is still really really bad. I have to translate some stuff from Japanese to English for my work before the new year rolls around (I'm not a translator, but I'm the only person in the company who is bilingual enough to do translation so I sometimes get stuck translating stuff) and I thought I could cheese it and run everything through DeepL since it's all super straightforward and grammatically correct with no slang or anything. Simple business language. Fucking nope, errors everywhere and I ended up having to actually translate it all myself. I was really disappointed because I was hoping that I could finish early with machine translation and then read a book or something but I'm pretty sure my ass would be in hot water if I turned in what DeepL gave me.

Btw, a ton of official translations (fan and official) are done by machines these days and that's a big part of why they're so bad, because machine translation is awful and the actual "translator" doesn't actually know the language so they're incapable of catching the mistakes when they happen.

Anyone who is actually fluent in Japanese and English would know that machine translation still has an extremely long way to go.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
As someone who's followed the fan translation scene since the late '90s, which were focused on very well known titles (in those circles at the time) that just never made it overseas, like FFV and Star Ocean (the latter of which was hilariously controversial especially because DeJap blueballed everyone by claiming the lead translator's HD blew up back in 2001 or 2002 and asked for money lmao), I don't believe learning Japanese just to play video games is worth it especially in this day and age, mostly for a number of reasons.

Unless you specifically consume only Japanese media daily and use it proactively, you're not going to truly learn and comprehend the language and cultural history behind it, especially one that's so wildly different from English. That's not even getting into issues like nonsensical location jokes and references / skits that are extremely dated. There are lots of translators today, both by people who do it for a living or for fun or even AI / MTLs are getting in on the action, all of which pretty much renders that original "worth learning" part moot. On top of that, that's not even getting into the nightmare of localizations and the script purity question. Even with all of those compounded factors, there are people who still pushed through with it and there's a ton more people who know Japanese now than there was a decade or two ago, leaving a very saturated field of translators who are constantly fighting over rights to translate. There's also another thing in this thread that's worth pointing out too: most of the titles posted are either Sega Saturn, obscure PC-E or PS1/PS2 titles, the reason which is that the technology to actually inject and rewrite text, make sure it fits the boxes, etc. is a much more difficult task than translating the script itself wholesale. This is not even a new thing either, since you can find entire script translations on GameFaqs from the 90s and 00s long before the games even had working translation patches.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9523219
Linda Cube Again and Linda Cube Kanzenban are fifth gen remakes of the PC Engine CD title Linda Cube. A "psycho thriller and hunting RPG," protagonist Ken Challenger is chosen, along with his slightly crazy but devoted tomboy girlfriend Linda, to collect one male and one female of every species of animal on the planet of Neo-Kenya and upload them into a massive space ark before a giant meteorite destroys the planet and everything left on it in seven in-game years. As time passes, the weather and seasons change, and various animals and NPCs will only come out during certain conditions. The game features several novel systems, including dog party members which cannot be directly controlled. It also features three unique story scenarios which represent adjoined worlds and excellent art design from Japanese artist Cannabis. The first two scenarios are very violent and dramatic and the third is a joke scenario where everyone gets a happy ending.

>>9523268
Daikoukai Jidai 2 AKA Uncharted Waters: New Horizons, is a fifth gen remake of the cult classic Koei game, a pseudo-historical swashbuckling RPG which takes place during the Age of Exploration. Players can choose to play one of 6 different protagonists which feature different gameplay styles and intertwining storylines. The game has updated graphics and sound compared to the original console releases, which were also sadly censored when initially released in the West. It has an excellent score by Yoko Kanno and an unprecedented amount of freedom in how you approach playing the game, where the world map is a map of the original world.

Daikoukai Jidai Gaiden is a direct sequel/spinoff to Uncharted Waters: New Horizons. It only features two protagonists, allegedly so that they could go further in-depth with the storylines. It features extensive cameos from the original cast. One of the protagonists, Salvador, is the son of Khayr Ad-Din, AKA Redbeard, king of the corsairs and a major antagonist in the first game. His storyline gets much darker than those of the six protagonists in part two. The game features updated an updated tide and weather system which is meant to be more accurate than the previous game. Islamic regions will also not let you pray in their churches anymore, and Chinese ports are closed off to outsiders in an attempt to be more historically accurate. The coverart is by some famous furfag.

Cyber Doll is a yellow label (soft 18+) RPG for the Sega Saturn. Humans begin to fall apart and are forced to become cyborgs if they want to live. Wolkenkratzer is a 3D fighting rogue-lite game. A unique idea that has not been explored much since, you climb a tower fighting a random enemy from a certain tier on each floor. After you defeat each enemy, you can search the floor for loot, although there is a chance you will have to fight another enemy instead of successfully finding anything.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Hear me out... This was an experiment, and I think it went well.
I heard the Family Pocket was a fun and convenient device for the money and I thought "bullshit" but tried it because I was looking for cheaper gifts at the time and didn't want to setup and/or build a new device for the 50th time. It's not fun anymore.
I did take out the decoy cartridge and I did throw some other games on to test these silly Java emulators for NeoGeo and SNES, but that's it.
Metal Slug doesn't work. It won't pass the Yoshi's Island test, but I played Earthbound and Mario All Stars fine. Every GBC I've tried ran fine. All the NES and Genesis so far run fine.

It's all setup out of the box with a functioning UI in English, decent lists with boxart, easy save slot for each game, and instant on/off that (so far) seems to be about as safe as possible. I didn't swap the loaded SD for a better one yet so who knows? But six months of testing so far and no worries. I paid $25 for it. It looks and feels like a pickup and play toy and it is. Which I love.

I have several anbernic devices and so on, I'm not a pleb. I'm just sharing my findings on this. It's a really neat convenient affordable toy if you like the proposition.

(Also on a personal note, I love the sound. It isn't good although it has a vol wheel. But the mostly empty softer plastic case seems to smooth out all the bumpy squares and triangles in the sound waves of 8-16 bit games that make my ears thump uncomfortably without a great setup. I have this issue on my 351p with all settings possible tweaked. The smoothing resonance of the cheap case is a nice bonus for me.)
Thank you for liking and subscribing to my autistic review bastard blog

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9522563
There is literally a huge oversight in the level design. If you go into the last challenge room to get the gold key, if your water is up you need to drain it down by the end of the room. So essentially you clear the challenge, realize you're stuck, have to backtrack and drain the water at the start of the hub area, and do the challenge room again. You literally have no way of knowing how the water is supposed to be before you enter this room, and it's easier to get into the room if the water is raised. Either I'm missing some indication or it's a big fuckup. I doubt the devs were being cruel on purpose.
Not only that, in the saturn version, one of the silver keys is over a grey texture in a pretty incospicuous place, I passed over it 3 times before I was able to notice it, and I only did it because the camera was clipping through the floor and it gave it some contrast. And I was playing in RGB through SCART, lord knows how tough it is to see with a composite signal.
The cistern is no masterpice, but it could be if they fix these wrinkles.

>>9511906
>>9512063
I'm actually of the opinion that visual novels are better if Japanese isn't your first language.
I've read plenty of English visual novels and the experience can be somewhat unengaging, and they certainly don't feel like video games.
Reading a Japanese VN is much more involved. Looking up words, trying to learn them, and untangling sentences with twisted spaghetti grammar is quite stimulating. It honestly feels like playing a good puzzle game.
Like most puzzle games it can be really frustrating sometimesー I remember nearly pulling my hair out trying to figure out what the fuck 々 meant without knowing how to type or pronounce it. But overall it's mostly fair and mostly fun.
The extra time you spend with the story from your slow reading speed helps you get invested, and all the extra challenges you had to overcome really makes it feel earned when the cute anime girl you've fallen in love with tells you she loves you too.
In any case, ToHeart2 is an interesting title to look into even if you usually couldn't care less about visual novels. The PC version (XRATED) comes with a versus puzzle game and a shooting game, and the third entry Manaka de Ikuno!! comes with a trading card game and a full RPG. They're a lot of fun; it makes me wish more VNs had minigames.
If anyone here is interested in trying out XRATED, make sure you get the latest update, it adds a new character to the puzzle game.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9507519
I think this website alone proves that people who are against achievements in video games simply lack skill.

It was only when they were first introduced in the PS3 / 360 era that cheevos sucked. The go-to example of this is probably The First Templar (way too easy) or Gran Turismo 5 (requires a retarded amount of dedication) not to mention all of the online-only trophies which were functionally impossible to get.

Nowadays, while there are a lot of games releasing solely for trophy hunters to get an easy platinum, most other achievement lists are designed by the developers themselves rather than a third party. In my opinion, if retro devs had access to cheevo software back in the day, the lists they would have made might be quite similar to these fanmade ones - barring glitches and 1cc autism, of course.

My go-to pick for proof of why RetroAchievements is fantastic are the coin challenges in SMB1. Even when you consult a level map to get every coin possible, ratchet scrolling means you have to be basically perfect. There's also the ironman challenge for SMW, or the extra hard cheevos for F-Zero X. It's also worth mentioning that the API's implementation is a fantastic training tool for indie devs since you have to dive deep into the code and tinker with lots of stuff just to make a functioning trophy.

There are definitely games which don't need achievements at all. Like, no one is ever going to fucking care you got 100% in NES Bubble Bobble. I still believe that it's a necessary step towards helping the younger generation get into older games. I hated Balloon Fight and Clu Clu Land until I tried getting cheevos for them, and it showed me that in spite of their lack of content these games can be enjoyed for an insane amount of time if you're going for specific challenges.

In most video games for the Olympics, football/soccer, and team sports in general, were usually left out, with the main exception I can think of being... the Mario & Sonic franchise. 2020 was probably the best year in that regard, both Mario & Sonic at Tokyo 2020 and the official Tokyo 2020 video game feature football/soccer, and both have better turfs and lighting than eFootball still, which is sort of funny.

When it comes to video games that are 100% made with Olympic football/soccer in mind I can only think of Olympic Soccer 1996 and Winning Eleven 2000, with the latter actually being incredible to me.

I wish that we'd get these stand alone adaptations again, or maybe that the official Paris 2024 video game actually gives the sport more care and adds the official players and nations, anything but a bare bones DLC for EA Sports FC or eFootball that'll just be lost in time eventually, I want to be able to go back to a tournament like I can go back to any FIFA World Cup before 2018, when it became a DLC.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9522065
I agree with OP, Fourside is just weird and marks a big turn for worse in the game.
You go from soulful cities with lots of interesting places like school / arcade / mayor's house / flea market / etc., with lots of memorable characters, to a city where nothing really has as much soul and just isn't memorable.
Yeah, ok, you go on that psychedelic trip in that city. But what's the game after it? A pointless "world tour" in cliched gimmicky locations like the jungle / Egypt / Stonehenge / that fucking dinosaur land / etc. They feel empty and pointless, and completely ruin the atmosphere of the "'80s America". They've been building the world with those 3-4 interconnected cities, then they went and shat all over that.
It feels like the writers just gave up after Fourside.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9517445
I have only played Origins and Shattered Memories and didn't really like either.

Origins:
Pros:
>decent attempt to recapture the feel of the originals
>good atmosphere in a few areas, keeps use of fixed camera angles but they're awkward in a few areas
>brings back outdoor exploration from SH1
>good ost, as expected from Yamaoka
Cons:
>over emphasis on physical combat, made way more annoying then it needs to be because weapons have durability and you can carry unlimited weapons, so if you want a specific weapon you literally have to menu across dozens of weapons you picked up before it
>core mechanic is you can enter and leave the otherworld whenever you wish, this leads to a lot of samey "explore normal world, enter otherworld and interact with something, go back and use the change to the real world to progress" situations. Also it just makes the existence of otherworld in general less memorable
>story is pretty terrible. The game simultaneously tries to do a retread of the lore seen in SH1 and have the protagonist experience his own SH2 journey of self realization and neither comes close to being good. The SH1 characters act nothing like they did in the original making their motives and dialogue awkward and Travis' own story is both very generic and not even executed well
Overall a 6/10, just above average to be notable I would say but lacks the memorable aspects of prior games. as a lorefag the way they recontextualize so many aspects of SH1, from the cast to the lore, really annoys the fuck out of me but that's a more personal problem.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9517721
Shattered Memories:
Pros:
>looks great for a wii game, environments are well detailed and character models look mostly okay beside the faces I would say
>Yamaoka's last game for the series, not his greatest work but there's still some great tracks here
Cons:
>combat has been removed entirely, you have no means to defend yourself to any capacity. This could have been interesting if executed better but then this leads into the next major issue
>enemies only appear in scripted chase sequences. Not only do you spend most of the game with no tension since there's no danger, but even when enemies appear all you do is easily run away from them
>puzzles are terrible. A lot of them try too hard to incorporate the wiimote and feel more like playing some kind of dumb minigame then a thoughtful puzzle you have to think about
>exploration is weak, with no danger normally it's just you traversing linear layouts with little to do
>the "scares" are just from listening to voice messages of teenagers being retarded and putting themselves in dumb situations, they're not scary or even entertaining
>the game big appeal, the way it "psychoanalyzes" you, feels very cheap and literally punishes you for looking at things across the game. What you look at determines what kind of person your Harry is and you basically have "decent human being" and varying levels of him being a shitty person.
4/10. A lot of people seem to quite like this one and I just don't get it. It's not only essentially a walking sim, but a walking sim that punishes you for exploring by changing whatever outcome you may desire. I really don't get what people see in it but still recommend it, maybe you could get something more out of it.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9523318
Anon, you got it all wrong.

The original project, Room 302, was always intended to be connected to Silent Hill. It more seems like the connections were going to be very loose though, rather then tie into previous games through the use of elements like Walter and the cult. The real reason it came out wonky was because after SH2 Konami forced Team Silent to develope both SH3 and SH4 simaltaneously. Because if this Team Silent essentially split into two teams, a lot of the more key members went to work on SH3 while the sort of "B-Team" of Team Silent did SH4. A lot of people who did smaller roles in SH1/2 were forced into majpr positions with SH4, resulting in the muddled execution.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9495706
Adding more objectives on higher difficulties is the only good option the designers had. It's boring to just add more guards on a higher difficulty (which it does, but it's secondary to the new objectives) or the even worse option of changing their behavior. You're playing a stealth game, so the inability to kill guards is important to make sure you stay undetected and be more careful instead of: "Oh well, I was careless and got caught, time for a sword fight!" Having to get in a sword fight (or run away on difficulties that prevent killing) works, because Thief (or more accurately Thief 1) is meant to evoke tension and fear of getting caught and to stray you away from confrontation. The blackjack (note: there is no specific spot you have to hit guards with it, you can do it from any direction, even the front, provided they aren't in combat) works as a mechanic, because the choice to use it or not use it changes the way the game it played, if you knock guards out you get the burden of hiding their bodies, so other AI don't see them. And if you choose to not use the blackjack, then the only suitable playstyle is ghosting (not alerting anyone to the point where they start to search for you) which makes the game even more difficult to those who desire while also changing the way you play.
The beauty of Thief comes down to letting the player form a playstyle without having them pick a class or such, but from the game's mechanics, Thief gives you so much freedom of approach while only making restrictions when necessary.

Fair enough, but the way some stuff is being shown in Retrotech videos is misleading at best. I think he has a lot of very useful practical knowledge about fixing CRTs, but he should know when he's out of his depth on technical matters and just flat out tell people: "look, I'm not exactly sure about this but this is what I think is going on" or something along those lines. >>9516704
You can clean mold off VHS tapes. Open top case of VCR. Fast forward the tape. As its running, lightly press Qtip dipped in rubbing alcohol against the capstan so the tape runs across it. Cleans all the mold off. I've done it several times and saved some rare tapes this way.

4 is memorable for its art style and some of the twists, but, taken as a whole, it’s not quite as good as 3. Also the English release had some content removed but the Japanese version has an English patch.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9522032
it would not have been practical to localize Fudou Myouou Den using any of the commonly available Nintendo mappers. the game used Taito's X1-005 chip which was neither exactly like MMC1 or MMC3, and it also had 128 bytes of on-chip RAM. Fudou Myouou Den uses this RAM and the only workaround would be to put a commonly available ext. RAM chip in the cartridge, but nobody was going to waste an 8k SRAM for 128 bytes of storage space. so they had no choice but to rework the game for MMC1 which meant reducing the ROM size and removing several features that depended on the 128 RAM in the X1-005.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9522528
You're thinking too black and white. Sure there are instances where the original cart retains value after a dump, but in many instances it doesn't retain the full value, because there is a market of people who either want the data for preservation, or who want to have a game precisely because it the cart has unique data. Will it be worthless? No, of course not. Are there people willing to pay $3k for some unreleased and undumped proto of a C-tier game? Of course, sometimes people will even crowdfund it. Are there people willing to pay $3k for an unreleased but already dumped C-list game? Not nearly as many, and good luck crowdfunding it, because the data (what people crowdfund for) is now effectively worthless on its own.
Just think about it - if somebody posts a photo of an unreleased and undumped prototype cart, people lose their minds and beg for the data, run to social media and cry about hoarders and trying to concoct schemes to get the data. If the same cart has been dumped? Nobody will give a shit about it... because why would they?

Or think of it this way: if the owner of an undumped cart DOESN'T want to sell the cart, they can sell a ROM dump for a few hundred or whatever, keep the cart, and go on their way. However, if they release the ROM for free, their only way to recoup costs will be to actually sell the cart itself.

Sure, it sucks, but outside of generosity, there is no real reason for an owner of an undumped proto to release it for free.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
the breadbin C64 has unreliable, hot-running chips because MOS used an ancient and not very efficient 5-6 micrometer process from the 70s. the VIC-II in particular was quite power-guzzling as it's a very busy chip that has to perform all graphics functions, bus mastering, and RAM refresh, and its internal speed is 8Mhz. after three years of bungled attempts they switched to a modernized lower power 3 micrometer process which is what the C64C chips use.

so combination of some outdated tech and MOS not having especially good engineers.

>>9496654
Being poor third-worlders, at school we emulated the everloving shit out of those five games and G/S/C through VBA, usually sharing tips or teams. I played a common save in the library PC during recess with other three guys from my classroom, all doing a bit per day or picking one pokemon for the current team.
To be honest, I went through the 3rd gen games because I liked the new pokemons, it was my entry to 1st gen and I wanted to play more of the franchise, but it always felt like a downgrade to the GBC games; no visible day/night cycle, the gimmicky base building and contests and the music were things I didn't like over the simpler, more dynamic experience from the previous generation. I guess things would have been different if I had played them on the hardware and had traded and battled with other people as it was intended.
If I had to choose, though, it would be Emerald. The Battle Frontier was a great time sinker once you found that one place you liked and went through again and again, in my case being the Factory and renting pokemons.

I'm talking about something a lot greater than little callbacks or references. I'm talking about having a real plot and a main narrative that gets fleshed out, not reinvented, when Pokemon was brand new and not just another series that everybody knew the "rules" of how the franchise works, a lot of us viewed it differently. We expected our adventure in Gen1 and everything it presented from intriguing Pokemon bios, the cryptic story of Mew/Mewtwo etc, and even things from the anime to be laying the groundwork for some bigger narrative, but it wasn't...and that's where the disappointment lies. I remember being a kid and playing Saphire version and enjoying the gameplay well enough but just thinking "oh, so that's it....we're in a new region and there's a new narrative with new creatures, that really doesn't elaborate on or build off the last and creates its own new semi self contained story/mythology" and it was then I knew that's how Pokemon was going to work as a franchise, and it worked for them, keeping things fairly new each time is part of why it's so successful and easily adopted by each new era of kids, but it still disappointed a lot of us. If you came into Pokemon post Gen 1 when the rules of how Pokemon works as a franchise were established, it's probably hard to imagine a time when nobody knew that and assumed every little tiny detail in Gen 1 was a big deal that had something to do with a greater story

In retrospect, obviously not much thought went into the plot, but it didn't feel that way to us as little kids who took it very seriously

That's a tough choice. I think I'd have to go with FRLG over Emerald if only because I've replayed it more. It's been a long time since I've played either of these games though, and I liked both of them. I see Emerald as a better version of Ruby or Sapphire, but I also liked Ruby a lot.
This was easily my favorite generation of Pokemon games. I only played gens 1, 3, 4 and 6 though. I'm sure I missed out on some good stuff with GSC, but I at least played SoulSilver.

I should say that I both understand how FRLG seems like a soulless rehash to many people and personally think it's one of the nicest-looking, best-playing games in the series, if that makes sense. I played Red and Yellow before I played FireRed and honestly don't really prefer one version over the other. I think the original games had better music and a handful of better lines of dialogue, but FRLG was pretty great otherwise. I like held items, natures and all the other gen 3 junk and honestly like being able to play Red or Green with that stuff thrown in. I liked the way the Pokedex was presented and how the game gives you a little recap of what you last did whenever you load a save. The Sevii Islands were boring though, and the battle sprites should have been animated like they were in Emerald.

I actually preferred Ruby/Sapphire because it at least was something new for its time. It did a lot of cool things and to me really freshened up the series up to that point. The only thing it missed was doing the physical/special split for attacks. That came a gen later. Would have been sweet to see it introduced with R/S/E instead. Was probably the most logical change to ever come to this franchise but by the time it showed up I was already done with Pokemon so I never played past the third gen of games. It was also nice to see those secret bases be a thing even if there was only a few limited locations for it. Was nice you could link up with friends, even have your friends character persist in your world. The fashion shows were also a fun divergence from the main game. Something this series desperately needed instead of just constant battling. Also made lesser mons and attacks not always completely worthless. Just too bad it was never expanded on really to my knowledge. Pokemon should have went out its way to vastly expand on concepts outside the catching and battling but I guess that leaves no room for milking so of course it wasn't happening.

Now as for the GB/GBC era, I actually prefer this era. Especially R/B/Y games. Its just preference and nostalgia admittedly. I also though prefer the look of this era to the later gens. Some gameplay and ideas from later games inserted into these older looking games instead would be perfect to me. One day I'll get around to those fan games or romhacks.

I just replayed Green. I used Bulbasaur exclusively til Bill, then added a Meowth that I let level up against trainers on 24/25 I'd skipped plus Misty's gym. Next I added a Vulpix after the Rock Tunnel, then after beating Erika I got the Super Rod and caught a Poliwag - at level 15. I had it level up on the way up through Silph Co, got a Lapras (also level 15), and then went down Cycling Road and beat Koga. I got a lvl 32 Magneton in the Power Plant and then went back to Fuchsia, up the eastern routes, finished Silph, the Saffron gyms, and then worked my way through the late-game content. While I will admit that I did not use Repels and fought nearly every wild Pokemon I encountered, at no point did I have to grind to keep my team's average level sufficiently high to handle all threats, all the way to Mewtwo. Closest to it was using the Rare Candies I found once I reached the Elite 4. Most players will not have two level 15 mons join the party halfway through the game, and as such will have to do even less grinding than me unless they try to use the shitmons like the early route fodder in the latter half of the game.

posts.com:
My recommendations for order play through and platform.

1. RE 96 or Directors cut (non-dual shock) PS1 on CRT
2. RE2 '98 PS1 or DC on CRT
3 RE3 '99 PS1 or DC on CRT
4. CODE VERONICA X (GCN or "PS2 Classic" version on PS4, stay away from the PS2 version and the HD MT Framework versions)
5. REmake PC or GCN + CRT
6. RE0 PC or GCN + CRT
7. Biohazard Outbreak Files 1+2 w/English patch on pscx2 with online via the outbreak resurrection server
8. RE4 PC + HD mod or GCN on CRT
9. RE5 GOLD PC
10. Revelations 1+2 PC
11. RE6 PC
12. RE7 GOLD PC
14. RE8 GOLD PC

Gits and shiggles if you really enjoy the series:
Umbrella Chronicles/Darkside Chronicles on Wii/Dolphin, Gun Survivor 2 w/ light gun or mouse

If you are a completionist:
RE Gaiden GBC and Gun Survivor JPN w/ lightgun

One thing I really appreciate about fighting games are how transferable the skills are.
If I get stuck against a hard boss I can take a long break, play other fighting games, and come back in a few months better than when I left.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9505037
Depends. Fighting games generally have an arcade mode that has you fight AIs but older especially tend to have hard ones, especially if you play the arcade versions. Some fighting games also have difficulty settings in the options, which could help to ease you in, depending on the game.
I'm far from an expert, but speaking personally, I found that Soulcalibur and Capcom vs SNK helped me quite a bit: SCI gives you a decent amount of moves to do through buttons and directionals rather than inputs and the Groove system in Capcom vs SNK was what pushed me to learn how inputs work (although getting to Akuma was next to impossible for me until I got lucky). The A.I. in CvS1 can be hard if it gets in the mood though (Ryu in particular is a pain in the ass, but still doable if you aren't worrying about Groove too much).

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9494516
I don't find fighting games a lot of fun to play in single player desu, I think it's because they rely so much on reading your opponent and trying not to get read yourself, and that element just doesn't really exist against a CPU beyond figuring out their rudimentary pattern. You can't mix up a CPU, and whether you block their mix-up can come down to pure luck whereas against a human it's not ALL luck, even if it's unreactable. If enemies in single-player action games had unreactable mix-ups it'd be considered pure BS and that's what you're dealing with sometimes when playing against CPUs. It's like playing poker against a computer, it feels kinda pointless.

Although doing combos against CPUs can be fun, since in most fighting games once you begin a combo the game essentially becomes a single-player rhythm game until the combo ends. Fighting games are a weird genre.

>>9517024
for me MGS excels when it's set indoors and close quarters, 3 is when the mgs started shying away from indoor area focus. They tried to make it work with the jungle/natural areas, but it doesn't even come close to 2's areas. Best areas in mgs3 are, Rassvet, Bolshaya Base, Graniny Gorki and Groznyj Grad, here you can experiment and fuck around with the guards so much, but it's only 4 areas compare to mgs2's sea of repayable areas.
Also the menu stuff kills the pacing, granted most mgs player don't really bother with the camo stuff if they sneak properly with a well-around camo, but the backpack stuff and healing just kills the pacing, and if you put a bunch of stuff on snake, he'll lose his stamina faster.
I understand they wanted to add more depth but I don't think this gen was not the right time to do it...that is if loading limitations was the reason they went in this direction.
Either that or devs were still figuring out stuff that's standard now, or didn't play games that had some quality of life features that might've made things smoother. Like the dpad could've been used to access camos and backpack items faster by holding a dpad button and have a ratchet style weapon wheel pop up, but for backpack items and camo for quick switching. They could've even used the left shoulder button item selection have 1 slot dedicated to camo only for faster switching, like Raiden's costume slot in 2 but you can toggle different outfits on the fly, like you would with the suppressor on a gun in 3, or ammo types in 4. Here you would've equipped 4 camos to switch on the fly, you can even make the switch subtle by having Snake quickly change clothes inside a cbox like in 5, it would increase the pacing a lot, even with that short cbox animation.
Easy Stalking could've been assigned to a different button that you can just hold, it didn't need to use 4 buttons, the game didn't even need it in the 1st place when stalking is possible with the left stick.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
There's this quirk with Megaman 4-6 where the charging sound won't play under certain conditions, like, if the channel is busy playing something else at the moment when the charging sound should start playing. You can achieve this for example, by letting go of a charge then pressing the button again right after, if you time and aim it right, you'll start charging when the channel is busy playing the hit/explosion sound and you'll get a silent charge that lasts until you let go. Lately when I do buster only replays of those games I try to time my shots to get silent charges as much as I can, so I can enjoy the music more. It's a fun little diversion from just playing the regular way.

I believe the channel also gets muted during screen transitions so you can time it with those too? I don't know all the details to be honest, but I wonder if any of those autists that like to dissect game code have ever figured out the exact conditions during which this happens, would be fun to know.

The still screens were designed around making things you were supposed to find easily visible, so if you play a freeroam version without having played the original first, it's very easy to miss things that were never meant to be hard to find.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9518548
It was extremely significant at the time and is an important point on the timeline of how videogames progressed, so if you're interested in that which the people here who aren't just literally autistic and refuse to play anything they haven't played 1000 times before presumably are it's worth playing just for that reason. It's also a 3D art style that existed in the 90s where fidelity was starting to get to where things are recognizable and nice looking but still very artificial, it gives art like this a dreamlike quality and, at least to me, gives a powerful feeling of what the tech world was like generally back then, I can't look at myst without remembering stuff like the transition from dos to windows, the optimism, just that time period in general and I think that would come through even for someone without memories of that time. It's not a terribly exciting game, but it wasn't back then either. Play it to experience what we considered top of the line art and technology back then, don't expect it to be some kind of thrill lol. It's an adventure game.

>extremely significant at the time
Yeah, but it was mainly because CD-ROM craze. It sold in absurd numbers, but was it really that influential, besides spawning a ton of imitators? First person adventure games were nothing new, and neither was environmental storytelling. Without that, Myst only has graphics. I guess you can say that modern walking sims lifted the storytelling tropes from mystoids, but they didn't do it directly - they evolved by themselves from first person horrors like Amnesia and the particular breed of HL mods.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9518646
It literally pioneered pre-rendered graphics and environmental storytelling. You're going to say no its some other retarded obscure game, but yes, it did. It was a popular game that proved that both concepts could be relevant and it is extremely historically important. The way that Myst told its story, along with the manner the world presents things is a massive precursor to many games that would be released after it.

Also, even till this day, when the art is at its best (e.g. Sirrus's rooms) it is beautifully detailed. FYI, I played Myst for the first time this year, so no, I'm not nostalgiaing over it. The game has great design for its time and is a foray not only into environmental storytelling, but storytelling period in games. Just compare the stories of games that came before Myst and you'll see what I mean.

Myst and Myst Masterpiece Edition are identical in content, but Masterpiece has better audio and color depth compared to the original release. Play Masterpiece Edition if you want less dithering. The only version released after Masterpiece Ed that I can recommend is the first remake, RealMyst (2000), Not to be confused with RealMyst: Masterpiece Edition (2014), or Myst (2020). Realmyst has a lot of minor visual inconsistencies with the original game, but I felt that it preserved the visual tone in realtime 3D better than the sort of tacky 2014 version. I haven't played 2020 Myst, but it doesn't look great, and is and even bigger departure than any of the other remakes.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
You really just need to look at Castlevania 64's contemporaries to see where everything went wrong.

>Super Mario 64
>Ocarina of Time
>Final Fantasy 7
>Metal Gear Solid
>F-Zero X
>Star Fox 64

In a generation where virtually every 2D series worth their salt was making a successful transition to 3D, Castlevania fucked up massively. Even Legacy of Darkness couldn't fix it. People love to go on about its atmosphere these days, but back then, the game looked, played, and sounded like shit compared to everything around it. Worse, CV64 was one of the WORST games in the series at the time, released after Symphony of the Night showed what a modern Castlevania could look like in 2D. 64 failed on every meaningful level to deliver that same quality in 3D.

I hate that people like this game now. I really do.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9518542
>>9518605
Decompiling is a pain, and usually, you will need to sort out a lot of things by yourself.
Even if decompilers now can separate code from data (which is helped in consoles starting at PS1 gen because some sort of memory formatting was common) you will likely end up with assembly with variable and functions name meaning nothing.
Well, at least, I tried it for the game boy, and so it was.
I don't see why PS1 would be different (except maybe if they let the debug symbols on the final CD? That's not unheard of, but quite rare).

Anyways, good luck, and enjoy your project!
It you can post your advancements here, that would be really great.

What game do you want to decompile?

>https://tetracorp.github.io/tokimeki-memorial/methods/decompiling-psx-games.html
>https://www.reddit.com/r/REGames/comments/lkbzei/how_to_get_started_decompiling_psx_games/ (I know, Reddit, but, hey, this is sensible for once.)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9520325
The Jetsons Invasion of the Planet Pirates comes to mind.
As a licensed game developed by Taito for the SNES, they re-used the game engine and level designs for another licensed game in Japan; Youkai Buster: Ruka no Daibouken.

The game is mostly the same, but the key differences aside from the change in characters and visuals, is a different intro cutscene, the introduction of bonus levels after each action level's boss fight, a whole new final boss, and the inclusion of additional cheat codes whilst the game is paused. The game is however two levels shorter, not all levels were converted from the original game, but some mini-game segments were put in their place.

Whichever version you play though, it is a genuinely good game, nothing amazing, but worth a play.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9522219
I don't get the appeal of focusing so much on numbers, to me it's all about the experience of playing most of all really, but to each their own I suppose, so here are my recommendations for you, OP...

1. QuackShot (Sega Genesis): It's not a complete piece of cake, but it's really enjoyable and well made, short and has unlimited continues, so as long as you keep going it should be a matter of time.

2. World Cup Italia '90 (Sega Genesis): I'm not sure if you're into football/soccer, but this is a simple one, a tournament of 7 matches, just spam diagnoal long balls and try to do a header or bicycle kick.

3. Sonic Chaos (Sega Master System/Sega Game Gear): I'd say this is the easiest 2D Sonic platformer ever made, just keep going to the right and you'll beat it, if you want 100% completion though...

4. Lucky Dime Caper & Deep Duck Trouble (Sega Master System/Sega Game Gear): A similar situation to QuackShot, they're both good, fun and short, with unlimited continues, just keep playing them.

5. World Cup Italia '90 (Sega Master System): Another 7 match tournament, just select a good team like Brazil, run up the pitch or do long passes, and score by passing it sideways near the box.

6. Donald Duck no Mahou no Boushi (SNES): A straightforward adventure even on the hardest difficulty setting, same situation as the previous Donald Duck titles I've mentioned, and a good time too.

7. Crash XS & Crash 2 (GBA): Lovely adaptations of Crash's PS1 gameplay into 2D, completing them 100% isn't so simple, but just getting to the end should give you much trouble at all, both are a good time.

I hope I was able to help out, OP. I'd say there are lots of titles you could try, but there's are just the ones that came up to my head for some reason, hope that you can beat them, but most of all, have fun doing it.

First off, game sales are much higher today in general due to bigger market and higher install bases. SNES sold ~50 million units total, N64 did ~32 mln units. By comparison, 3DS sold ~75 mln, and Switch is already at over 118 mln.
Second, you ignore just HOW big Rare was for Nintendo in SNES/N64 eras. The 3 DKC games on SNES sold over 17 mln copies combined (add Killer Instinct for another 3,2 mln games) and helped Nintendo beat Genesis in sales in late 90s. Goldeneye sold 8 mln and was the 3rd biggest N64 game only after SM64 and MK64, and was one of the most major selling points of the console. Combined, Rare's games sold over 28mln on N64.
It was about as important for SNES/N64 as Square was for PSX. That is, very fucking important.

Colony Wars 3: This space combat sim is known for its immersive gameplay and engaging storyline, but one of the standout features of the game is its soundtrack. The music, composed by Tim Wright and Jason Page, perfectly captures the mood of each mission and adds to the overall atmosphere of the game. The mix of electronic and orchestral elements creates a unique and exciting audio experience that really enhances the gameplay.

Pro Skater 2: This classic skateboarding game is not only fun to play, but it also boasts a fantastic soundtrack featuring a variety of punk, rock, and hip hop tracks. The music really helps to set the tone for each level and adds to the overall energy of the game.

Jade Cocoon: This role-playing game features a beautiful and atmospheric soundtrack composed by Norihiko Hibino and Atsushi Kitajoh. The music, which blends traditional Japanese instruments with modern electronic elements, perfectly captures the game's setting and adds to the overall sense of mystery and wonder.

Final Fantasy Tactics: This classic tactical RPG features a sweeping and epic soundtrack composed by Hitoshi Sakimoto. The music perfectly captures the mood of each battle and adds to the overall grandeur of the game's story.

Akuji the Heartless: This action-adventure game features a dark and atmospheric soundtrack composed by Ron Fish. The music helps to set the mood for each level and adds to the overall sense of dread and tension in the game. The mix of electronic and orchestral elements creates a unique and immersive audio experience that really enhances the gameplay.

China made factories in the 80s specifically destined to make NES clones. It was a part of the deng xiaoping policy to flood the global electronics market with cheap clones. They still have the tools now and are still making them, but theyre now more compact models than the original one.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9518059
Originally they just decapped the NES chipset and copied them directly with pin compatible 2A01/PPU clones. Later on they went to a single chip implementation on a more modern CMOS process, although they slightly messed it up and got the 2A01 duty cycle wrong so sound is a little off in these one chip NOACs.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9518059
The Mega Drive had mostly off the shelf parts except the VDP, but the SNES was all bespoke chips except for RAM, and some pretty advanced ones with a lot of features.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9518126
The 68000 and Z80 are no big deal to implement (besides you can still get new Z80s for embedded use), the VDP is more complex but still doable, with only the YM2612 being an issue as it has analog components. The SNES PPU is however a quite complex chip with multiple operating modes and other features the relatively straightforward VDU lacks, and later single chip versions were not exactly like the earlier dual chip ones.

>>9518169
As anon said, originally they just copypasted the NMOS logic from the NES chips. when they went to NOACs a newer CMOS process was used so the logic had to be re-implemented, but they messed some things up in the process of converting it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Games designed for Famiclones often won't work on real NES as they don't use or need OAM refresh--the PPU used on-chip DRAM due to early 80s technical constraints, but these clones were made later with newer processes that allowed SRAM to be fit on the PPU die, thus no refresh required.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9518132
A large chunk of the VDP was wasted on Master System compatibility which is useless for a MD clone anyway. Otherwise it's pretty much like a bigger better PPU--a sprite/scrolling engine with more colors/sprites/layers. The SNES however has...

>a lot more colors (262,144 versus 512)
>hi res 512x448 interlaced mode
>several color depths
>three scroll layers instead of two
>sprite rotation/scaling

You see how they couldn't even fit it all on one chip until the later SNES revisions, two ICs were needed.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9517761
>What about link cable support on GB/C/A games? Can you demonstrate this feature while paired with an original console? No!

For the GB/GBC, yes. The cores support it over the SNAC connection and there are SNAC cables for it.

For GBA currently no, the core does not support it yet, but the hardware is capable if the core got updated to support it.

>What about utilizing custom chips on cartridges to expand features on consoles?

It currently supports every expansion chip except those two SNES Mahjong games that had ARM co-processors on them. It even supports the SPC-7110 games, something not even SNES flashcarts support, and the homebrew "custom" SNES expansion chips like the MSU-1 or the additional custom hardware in the Atari 7800 version of Rikki and Vikki, of which only a single software emulator is able to run.... and only because the developer of the game made that emulator specifically to run his game on PCs.

I had exactly the same experience, it's very fiddly and annoying to build. Especially that not where you have to drop the nuts down that weird hole then try and screw the bolt in and grasp the nut and permanently lock it in. Not as erotic as it sounds. There were also a few holes that still had material in. Had to drill out one completely. The buttons weren't quite long enough so had to glue some card shims on. Basically, lots of little problems that aren't deal breakers on their own but together make it super annoying and not worth the money.
But that's just the case. The board itself is a completely different story, it's really nicely laid out, some cool features other boards don't have (I like the SCART connector even if it's a stupid thing to put on instead of a Saturn-style DIN, the hdmi switches helped solved a problem with syncing and not having ports on every face means you can actually put it in an AV rack.
On the whole I'm happy with it, though. It gets far more use than any other retro system/emulsion box/whatever you want to call it.

>>9520506
>>9521525
>>9521590
Input lag can definitely be a perceptible problem, but there's both people who dramatically oversell its existence, prominence, and impact, as well as those trying to pretend that it's actually nothing.
In truth, input lag can vary widely for a very large amount of different reasons, given how different games work differently, different displays work differently, and different software emulators and hardware emulators differ amongst each other as well as original hardware, along with potential settings, there's hundreds of variables determining what kind of input lag you can be looking at. In many cases it truly isn't perceptible, others may be subtly perceptible, and some where it has an appreciable impact on the player's experience without them having to be a turbo-autistic speedrunner who can do arbitrary code execution in their sleep.
It's cumulative.

https://youtu.be/b3tbcUszA2s?t=515

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9521525
You're right, I can get used to it, but why would when there are solutions for mitigating it and in other cases completely eliminating it?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9521749
I appreciate what the section of the video you linked demonstrates which justifies some of my own research and adds merit to what people have taught me from different retro gaming communities. This is why I am really interested in the MiSTer and frequently visit my locals to play the one they set up since I can't afford my own yet. The FPGA itself doesn't have any lag; and disregarding how accurate the core is, so the program gets sent out as is. Further down the pipeline is where the potential accumulative lag begins to be introduced.

>Input Device
You can either use the direct serial port to interface original hardware via SNAC. Direct serial has no inherent lag, but even an OEM controller might have some, yet not enough that you won't notice. USB on the other hand has to translate your inputs at the OS level which might add delay but nowhere near half a frame so it is up to you to choose a device that has an encoder with the least amount of delay.

see:
MiSTer Input Latency Database [full detailed sheet linked on the page]
https://rpubs.com/misteraddons/inputlatency

>Game itself
Some games have a different kind of delay due to how the programmer affixed the sprite flow and input command as well as other underlying programming variables which might cause undesirable performance. Some of these inconsistencies can be fixed or changed by the community as needed.

>Display
In my opinion, playing over a CRT display is the optimal way to play the MiSTer. There are plenty of options that will suit people of all budgets. As for digital displays, you have an abundance of choice and you will get the best results with a "gaming" monitor designed to provide the least amount of lag.

Or, you can just buy each console you want to play for peace of mind that you are experiencing the game as originally intended.
